content: Can't be racial. French are not a separate race. But it is a derogatory nick name based on their eating of frog legs, like krauts for Germans, limeys for British, and doughboys or dogfaces for Americans . .. . The metaphor worked for me - - Wandering and Wondering
reply: Can't be racial. French are not a separate race. But it is a derogatory nick name based on their eating of frog legs, like krauts for Germans, limeys for British, and doughboys or dogfaces for Americans . .. . The metaphor worked for me - - Wandering and Wondering
title: Frogs jump pirate 'mothership'

title: Frogs jump pirate 'mothership'

content: quote: Originally posted by greywolfghost: But it is a derogatory nick name based on their eating of frog legs, That's what I thought for years but the term was actually given to the french in WWI by the Tommies because of their uniforms. The french had shoulder board epallepes which the Tommies called frogs. It's was how the Tommies knew that they were french that was running away. But actually that and many stories about how that name came into use and many have nothing to do with frogs as amphibian creatures.
quote: Originally posted by greywolfghost: But it is a derogatory nick name based on their eating of frog legs,
reply: That's what I thought for years but the term was actually given to the french in WWI by the Tommies because of their uniforms. The french had shoulder board epallepes which the Tommies called frogs. It's was how the Tommies knew that they were french that was running away. But actually that and many stories about how that name came into use and many have nothing to do with frogs as amphibian creatures.

content: Well, the French Foreign Legion used the be the Cream of the Crop until they took the triple whammy of not winning much fame in World War I, falling under Hitler's rule in World War II, and then receiving the final blow of getting their azz kicked at Dien Bien Phu... It would be nice to see France step back into the "Protector International" role again, but I think they are literally too gun-shy... Notice that we, to a lesser extent, are going through some of the set backs (Korea, Viet Nam, Iraq, Afghanistan) that might make us just as reluctant and paralyzed to act decisively - - Wandering and Wondering
reply: Well, the French Foreign Legion used the be the Cream of the Crop until they took the triple whammy of not winning much fame in World War I, falling under Hitler's rule in World War II, and then receiving the final blow of getting their azz kicked at Dien Bien Phu... It would be nice to see France step back into the "Protector International" role again, but I think they are literally too gun-shy... content: Forces from France's ship Nivose intercept Somali pirates April 15, 2009, in this picture released by the French Ministry of Defence. REUTERS/ECPAD-SIRPA MARINE-French Ministry of Defence/Handout A French navy helicopter escorts a commercial ship in the Gulf of Aden, January 2009. Somali pirates released an Asian chemical tanker they captured five months ago but still held at least 17 other ships as high-seas attacks in 2009 soared to record levels. (AFP/File/Stephane de Sakutin) Abduhl Wali-i-Musi, accused of hijacking the Maersk Alabama and taking its captain Richard Phillips hostage, is led into a federal building in New York April 20, 2009. The sole surviving Somali pirate from the hijacking is being tried in New York and is scheduled to appear in court Tuesday morning. REUTERS/Eric Thayer (UNITED STATES CONFLICT SOCIETY IMAGE OF THE DAY TOP PICTURE)
